1 Journal of Molecular Catalysis, 36 (1986) 253 - 269 253 CATALYSTS PREPARED BY THE INTERACTION OF TRANSITION METAL TETRAHYDROBORATES WITH OXIDE SUPPORTS: SYNTHESIS OF SURFACE Ti, Zr, Hf HYDRIDES AND THEIR CATALYTIC PROPERTIES IN ETHYLENE POLYMERIZATION G. A. NESTEROV, V. A. ZAKHAROV Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090 (U.S.S.R.) V. V. VOLKOV and K. G. MYAKISHEV Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, Novosibirsk 630090 (U.S.S.R.) (Received May 8,1986; accepted March 17,1986) Summary Surface hydride compounds of Ti, Zr and Hf were synthesized by supporting tetrahydroborate compounds of these metals on siUca and alumina, followed by their heating in vacuum. The resulting surface hy- drides are shown to be direct precursors of active centers of ethylene poly- merization. The catalytic properties of these systems synthesized in ethylene polymerization are studied. Introduction Transition metal hydrides are intermediates of many catalytic reac- tions, such as hydrogenation, hydroformylation, polymerization and others. By the present time, a great number of soluble individual hydride complexes have been synthesized and examined [1-5]. However, for solid catalysts only limited data on methods of synthesis, investigation of composition and catalytic properties of surface hydride compounds are available. In most cases the formation of surface hydride compounds is only postulated. Treatment of surface organometallic compounds by hydrogen proved to be an efficient way to prepare transition metal surface hydride com- pounds. As found in [6-9], surface hydrides of titanium and zirconium hydrides obtained by this way are very active in olefin polymerization [6, 8], as well as in the dehydrogenation and isomerization of olefins [9]. We have suggested recently a new way to synthesize surface hydrides [10, II], by supporting transition metal tetrahydroborate compounds on silica and alumina with further heating, during which surface hydrides of the corresponding elements are formed. Numerous covalent tetrahydroborate compounds of transition metals, lanthanides and actinides are known which can be used for synthesis of 0304-6102/86/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 254 surface hydrides of the said metals. Structures and properties of covalent tetrahydroborates have been studied in detail [2-5]. In these compounds, the tetrahydroborate ligand [BH4] is linked with metal by bridge hydrogen /^ /H /^v bonds of the type M( )B' or M H^B H. Covalent tetrahydroborate 'H7 'H ^ compounds of transition metals are characterized by high volatility, solu- bility in aliphatic solvents, high reactivity, and in some cases by a higher thermal stability as compared to ff-organometallic compounds of transition metals. In the present work, data on the composition of surface compounds prepared by supporting Ti, Zr and Hf tetrahydroborate compounds on silica and alumina, and on their transformation to surface hydrides of these metals are presented. The interaction of surface Ti, Zr and Hf hydrides with ethylene and carbon monoxide has been studied; data have been obtained on catalytic properties of these systems in ethylene polymerization. Experimental procedure Silica with a surface area of 280 m2 g~1, pore volume 1.6 cm3 g~1 and alumina (S = 300 m2 g~1, V= 1.0 cm3 g~1), were used as supports. Before supporting tetrahydroborate compounds, the supports were heated in air for 6 - 8 h at 730 K, then in vacuum for 2 - 4 h at the required temperature. Ti(BH4)3, Zr(BH4)4, Hf(BH4)4 samples were prepared by conventional techniques [12 -14] through exchange reactions between metal chlorides and LiBH4. An intensive milling of reagents was performed using a ball vibration mill, followed by evolution of tetrahydroborate compounds from the reaction mixture via sublimation in vacuum. Catalysts were obtained in all-sealed apparatus using a glass partition technique. The pre-dehydroxylated silica and alumina were treated with pentane solutions of tetrahydroborate compounds at room temperature. Excess reagents were removed by washing the catalysts with pentane or by evacuation. Samples thus obtained will be subsequently referred to as 'initial'. Activation of initial catalysts was carried out by heating in vacuum at 350 - 570 K. Polymerization of ethylene was performed in a steel autoclave (0.2 1) by intensive stirring in hexane medium. During the polymerization, eth- ylene pressure and temperature were maintained constant (6 atm and 353 K). IR spectra were registered using UR-20 and Specord-75 IR spectro- meters within the range 1200 - 4000 cm"1 at 163 - 293 K in a special cuvette that allows heating of the support plate in vacuum, supporting a complex on it, heating of the catalyst and adsorption of reagents. NMR and EPR spectra were registered using, respectively, JNM-4H-100 and JES-3BX instruments. 255 Results and discussion Synthesis and identification of surface Ti, Zr, Hf hydrides Interaction of tetrahydroborate compounds with silica and alumina When supported on silica and alumina, tetrahydroborate compounds of Ti, Zr, Hf interact with surface hydroxyl groups by the reaction (E-OH),, + M(BH4)^ (E-0-)- M(BH4) -n + nHz + nBHa (I) (1) where E = Si, Al; M = Ti, Zr, Hf; n = 1, 2; m = 3, 4. Two groups of absorption bands for surface hydrides can be distin- guished (Table 2): 1560 -1730 cm~1 and 1925 -1975 cm"!. Bands in the range 1560 -1730 cm"1 are observed for practically all samples, prepared using both tetrahydroborate M(BH4)4 compounds and organometallic MR4 (R = CaHs, CHaCfiHs) complexes (Table 2). The position of these bands depends mainly on the nature of metal: P(M H) increases in the order: Ti < Zr < Hf. Absorption bands in the range 1925 -1975 cm"1 are observed only for systems prepared with the use of tetrahydroborate complexes (Table 2). Appearance of the two groups of bands seems to be associated with the formation of hydride compounds of various composition. The content of different forms of surface hydrides depends on the conditions of catalyst activation. Thus, heating Zr(BH4)4/Si02 at 493 K in a closed volume without evacuation of reaction products results in the appearance of an absorption band at 1975 cm"1, further evacuation of the sample at 493 K diminishes the intensity of the band at 1975 cm~1 and gives rise to one at 1665 cm"!. It is quite probable that surface hydride compounds without boron-hydride Uganda have absorp- tion bands in range 1560 -1730 cm~1, whereas those with both boron-hydride ligands and M H bonds have absorption bands in the range 1925 -1975 cm"1. The high content of boron in heated catalysts (Table 1) is probably due to reactions (3) and (4), as well as to the formation of Ti, Zr and Hf borides which are known to be produced during the decomposition of M(BH4)4 (M = Zr, Hf) [26]. Weinberg and Evans [17] analyzed the system Zr(BH4)4/Al20a, heated in vacuum at 473 K, using inelastic electron tunneling. They failed to obtain absorption bands from zirconium hydrides. This is likely due to the prepara- tion of alumina, as described in [17], by oxidation of an aluminium film; frequencies of valent oscillations for hydroxyl groups of this sample differed from v(OH) J-AlfOs, used in our work. Correspondingly, values of absorp- tion bands from bridge and terminal bonds Zr H B and B H in [17] and in our work also differed. Moreover, the intensity of the absorption band at 1925 cm"1 from v(Zr H.) is considerably weaker upon heating at 475 K than at the 523 K temperature used in our work. EPR data (see below) indicate that the oxidation degree of a metal ion in a surface hydride compound of Ti(III) remains the same as in the tetrahydroborate complex to be supported. In the case of Zr and Hf, the majority of metal ions in surface compounds (III) is in a tetravalent state. As for surface hydride compounds of titanium obtained using Ti(BH4)a, titanium ions seem to be in a trivalent state. The surface Ti, Zr and Hf hydrides we obtained exhibit high thermal stability and do not decompose up to 600 K, as evidenced by IR data, whereas homogeneous hydride compounds are considerably less stable. Thus, a dimer complex of titanium [(C5Hs)2TiH]2 and a monomer complex of zirconium (CsHg)2Zr(H)BH4 decompose above 370 K [15,21]. The high thermal stability of the above samples appears to result from the rigid fixation of the hydride compound on the support surface at the expense of M 0 Si(Al) bonds, which prevents them from decomposing via a bimolecular interaction. In contrast to the known supported organometallic catalysts [6, 8], surface hydroxyl groups are nearly absent from the surface of supported tetrahydroborate catalysts due to reactions (2) and (3) (which are most pronounced for systems based on alumina), which makes the interaction of surface hydrides and alkyls with hydroxyl groups of supports impossible at elevated temperatures (> 373 K). Formation of M3* compounds in supported tetrahydroborate catalysts according to EPR data Initial Zr(BH4)4/SiC 2(Al203) and Hf(BH4)4/SiC>2(Al203) catalysts show no signals in the EPR spectrum. After heating in vacuum at 493 K, EPR 261 spectra of these systems show a signal from Zr(III) and Hf(III) ions, the content of which does not exceed 0.1% of the overall metal content in the samples. The content of Hf(III) is considerably (5-8 times) lower than that of Zr(III) at the same metal content of the catalyst. The content of Zr(III) in these systems is much lower than that in the supported organo- zirconium catalyst Zr(C3H5)4/Si02 activated by hydrogen at 473 K [27]. High values of ^-factors of Zr(III) ions (g = 1.990 for Zr(BH4)/Si02 and g = 1.982 for Zr(BH4)4/Al203) seem to be associated with the Zr H bond in accordance with the data of [4, 5, 27, 28]. The EPR spectra of initial TUBH^a/SiO^AliOa) catalysts exhibit signals from Ti(III) ions with parameters gi = 1.994, g; = 1.959, gy = 1.935 and go = 1.962. The amount of Ti(III) ions observed is 10 - 20% of the overall content of titanium in the catalyst. This suggests that most of the Ti(III) in the catalyst is in the form of surface associates and is not observed in the EPR spectrum. A crystalline Ti(BH4)3 has no signals in the EPR spectrum, while a solution of Ti(BH4)3 in pentane at 77 K produces a weak EPR signal of about 0.1% of the overall content of titanium in the solution. On increasing the temperature to 300 K, there is observed a symmetrical line from Ti(III) ions, the intensity of which is two orders higher than the intensity of the signal at 77 K and is about 10% of the overall content of titanium. This may be due to titanium hydroborate found in the solution as associated [Ti(BH4)3],;, which is accompanied by an increase of the constant of the exchange interaction between Ti(III) ions in associates (JS? 100 cm"1). On heating to 300 K, associates partly dissociate to yield monomer forms that appear in the EPR spectrum as a signal with go = 1.971 and H = 30 g. However, although the portion of monomer Ti(III) com- plexes considerably increases with increasing the temperature from 77 to 300 K, the majority of Ti(III) ions is found in solution in the form of associates. Therefore, when supporting titanium tetrahydroborate on SiOy, and AlaOg only 10 - 20% of Ti(BH4)3 is anchored on the support in the monomer form, while most Ti(III) ions appear to be in the form of sur- face associates and are not observed in the EPR spectra. Heating of initial Ti(BH4)g/Si02 and Ti(BH4)3/Al203 catalysts in vacuum at 423 K does not considerably affect the intensity and form of the EPR spectra. Interaction of surface hydride compounds of Ti, Zr and Hf with ethylene and carbon monoxide Interaction with ethylene Ethylene adsorbed on the initial surface tetrahydroborate compounds does not considerably change the IR spectra. The formation of active centers is comprised of the following steps: (a) formation of surface tetrahydroborate compounds (I) during the inter- action of M(BH4)4 with hydroxyl SiO^ and Al^Oy groups, (b) decomposition of compounds (I) producing surface hydrides (III), (c) alkylation of hydride compounds by ethylene with the formation of active centers, i.e. surface alkyi compounds of Ti, Zr and Hf. Weinberg and Evans [18] investigated the interaction of ethylene and propylene with Zr(BH4)4/Al2C 3 at 300 - 575 K. They found that polymers were formed only at temperatures above 400 K, where surface tetrahydro- borate compounds appeared to decompose to form zirconium hydrides. Upon ethylene adsorption at 120 K on initial catalysts Zr(BH4)4/SiC>2 (AlaOa), a signal with the shift 5 = 4.8 +0.1 ppm with respect to TMS ap- pears. This reaction, performed on the same catalysts activated by heating, results in the appearance of two signals in the PMR spectrum: A, with a 263 shift 5 = 4.8 0.1 ppm, and B, S = 1.1 0.1 ppm [29]. Upon evacuation of samples, signals A and B disappear. Further adsorption of ethylene at 120 K leads to their reduction. A small shift in signal A, as compared to that of free ethylene (6 = 5.32 ppm), and the presence of the same shift in signal in the PMR spectrum when ethylene is adsorbed on silica and on unactivated Zr(BH4)4/Si02, suggest that signal A corresponds to ethylene adsorption on surface centers of supports. Signal B may be attributed to ethylene adsorption on surface centers with zirconium or boron atoms. However, ethylene adsorption at 120 K on highly active Zr(CH2C6H5)4/Al203 (Table 3), without boron, produces signals A and B. This indicates that signal B is related to ethylene adsorption on surface zirconium ions. By the shift value (8 = 1.1 0.1 ppm), signal B has a position close to shifts of saturated compounds (5 = 1.1 -1.3 ppm). Disappearance of signal B during evacuation of the sample, however, does not permit ascribing it to an alkyi group bound with a zirconium ion or a polymer. Taking into account the correlation between the appearance of signal B and the formation of surface hydrides of zirconium (for initial unactivated Zr(BH4)4/Si02(Al203), no signal B is observed), one may attrib- ute signal B to ethylene adsorption on an active center with a zirconium hydride or an active Zf C bond. On raising the adsorption temperature above 120 K, a broad line from the polymer formed is observed. Catalytic properties of supported tetrahydroborate systems in ethylene polymerization Initial catalyst systems containing tetrahydroborate compounds of type: (E 0)nM(BH4),n-n show no activity in ethylene polymerization; 266 they become active only after heating. To activate samples such as Zr(BH4)4/ AlzOa and Ti(BH4)3/Si02(Al203), it suffices to heat them at polymerization temperature (353 K). With a further rise of temperature, their activity in- creases considerably (Fig. 5). For systems Ti(BH4)3/Si02(Al203), the optimal temperature for heating the initial catalysts was found to be 403 - 423 K. For systems based on Zr(BH4)4 and Hf(BH4)4, the maximum activity was observed after heating at 500 - 523 K (Fig. 5). A correlation exists between the onset of decomposition of surface tetrahydroborate compounds, the appearance of surface hydride compounds (IR data) and the appearance of catalytic activity. For example, when heating the Zr(BH4)4/SiOz system, absorption bands from surface hydride compounds appear in the IR spectra only above 423 K. At the same temperature the system becomes catalyt- ically active for ethylene polymerization (Fig. 5). The data on the activity of supported tetrahydroborate catalysts of various composition in ethylene polymerization are compiled in Table 3. The activity of supported catalysts depends on the composition of the complex to be supported and on the nature of the support. On the same support, the maximum activity was demonstrated by Zr(BH4)4, and de- creased in the order Zr > Hf > Ti. In the case of supported organometallic catalysts, systems prepared with organoztrconium compounds were also the most active [36-38]. Samples prepared using organozirconium and zirconium hydride compounds ZrR4 (R = BH4, 03115, CHaCgHs) have nearly the same activity. The catalytic properties of these systems synthesized in ethylene polymerization are studied.
